member.summary: Performs a build operation.
member.remarks: This operation uses the strategies and permanent policies already configured into the builder, combined with the optional transient policies, and starts a build operation. Transient policies override any built-in policies, when present.
member.param: The locator to be used for this build operation.
The to use for this build operation.
The transient policies to apply to this build. These policies take precedence over any permanent policies built into the builder.
The to use for this build operation.
The key of the object to build.
The existing object to run the build chain on, if one exists. If null is passed, a new object instance will typically be created by some strategy in the chain.
member.returns: The built object.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Practices.ObjectBuilder2.IRequiresRecovery
member.summary: This interface provides a hook for the builder context to implement error recovery when a builder strategy throws an exception. Since we can't get try/finally blocks onto the call stack for later stages in the chain, we instead add these objects to the context. If there's an exception, all the current IRequiresRecovery instances will have their Recover methods called.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Practices.ObjectBuilder2.IRequiresRecovery.Recover
member.summary: A method that does whatever is needed to clean up as part of cleaning up after an exception.
member.remarks: Don't do anything that could throw in this method, it will cause later recover operations to get skipped and play real havok with the stack trace.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Practices.ObjectBuilder2.IReadableLocator
member.summary: Represents a locator that can be read from.

remarks.para: A locator is a dictionary of keys to values, but it keeps the values with weak references, so that locating an object does not keep it alive. If you want to keep the object alive too, you should consider using an .

Locators have a built-in concept of hierarchy, so you can ask questions of a locator and tell it whether to return results from the current locator only, or whether to ask the parent locator when local lookups fail.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Practices.ObjectBuilder2.IReadableLocator.Contains(System.Object)
member.summary: Determine if the locator contains an object for the given key.
member.returns: true if the locator contains an object for the key; returns false otherwise.

member.summary: Strategies in this stage create objects. Typically you will only have a single policy-driven creation strategy in this stage.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Practices.ObjectBuilder2.BuilderStage.Initialization
member.summary: Strategies in this stage work on created objects. Typical work done in this stage might include setter injection and method calls.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Practices.ObjectBuilder2.BuilderStage.PostInitialization
member.summary: Strategies in this stage work on objects that are already initialized. Typical work done in this stage might include looking to see if the object implements some notification interface to discover when its initialization stage has been completed.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Practices.Unity.IUnityContainer.RegisterInstance``1(``0)
member.summary: Register an instance with the container.

remarks.para: Instance registration is much like setting a type as a singleton, except that instead of the container creating the instance the first time it is requested, the user creates the instance ahead of type and adds that instance to the container.
This overload does a default registration and has the container take over the lifetime of the instance.

member.typeparam: Type of instance to register (may be an implemented interface instead of the full type).
member.returns: The object that this method was called on (this in C#, Me in Visual Basic).

member.name: M:Microsoft.Practices.Unity.IUnityContainer.RemoveAllExtensions
member.summary: Remove all installed extensions from this container.

remarks.para: This method removes all extensions from the container, including the default ones that implement the out-of-the-box behavior. After this method, if you want to use the container again you will need to either readd the default extensions or replace them with your own.
The registered instances and singletons that have already been set up in this container do not get removed.

member.returns: The object that this method was called on (this in C#, Me in Visual Basic).

member.name: T:Microsoft.Practices.Unity.SynchronizedLifetimeManager
member.summary: Base class for Lifetime managers which need to synchronize calls to .

remarks.para: The purpose of this class is to provide a basic implementation of the lifetime manager synchronization pattern.

Calls to the method of a instance acquire a lock, and if the instance has not been initialized with a value yet the lock will only be released when such an initialization takes place by calling the method or if the build request which resulted in the call to the GetValue method fails.

member.summary: Retrieve a value from the backing store associated with this Lifetime policy.
member.returns: the object desired, or null if no such object is currently stored.

member.remarks: This method is invoked by after it has acquired its lock.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Practices.Unity.ObjectBuilder.UnityBuildStage.Setup
member.summary: First stage. By default, nothing happens here.

member.summary: Second stage. Type mapping occurs here.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Practices.Unity.ObjectBuilder.UnityBuildStage.Lifetime
member.summary: Third stage. lifetime managers are checked here, and if they're available the rest of the pipeline is skipped.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Practices.Unity.ObjectBuilder.UnityBuildStage.PreCreation
member.summary: Fourth stage. Reflection over constructors, properties, etc. is performed here.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Practices.Unity.ObjectBuilder.UnityBuildStage.Creation
member.summary: Fifth stage. Instance creation happens here.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Practices.Unity.ObjectBuilder.UnityBuildStage.Initialization
member.summary: Sixth stage. Property sets and method injection happens here.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Practices.Unity.ObjectBuilder.UnityBuildStage.PostInitialization
member.summary: Seventh and final stage. By default, nothing happens here.

member.summary: Run an existing object through the container and perform injection on it.

remarks.para: This method is useful when you don't control the construction of an instance (ASP.NET pages or objects created via XAML, for instance) but you still want properties and other injection performed.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Practices.Unity.UnityContainerBase.RemoveAllExtensions
member.summary: Remove all installed extensions from this container.

remarks.para: This method removes all extensions from the container, including the default ones that implement the out-of-the-box behavior. After this method, if you want to use the container again you will need to either readd the default extensions or replace them with your own.
The registered instances and singletons that have already been set up in this container do not get removed.

member.returns: The object that this method was called on (this in C#, Me in Visual Basic).
